research_results.title: 34 Best Things to Do in NYC - U.S. News Travel
research_results.content: Looking for the best things to do in New York City? Plan your trip with these expert tips for iconic attractions, including the Statue of Liberty, Broadway and more.

research_results.title: 25 Most Visited Tourist Attractions in New York City (Ranked)
research_results.content:
The Lincoln Center
The Lincoln Center is home to the Metropolitan Opera House, New York Philharmonic, New York City Opera, New York City Ballet, the School of American Ballet, Julliard School of Music, the Chamber Music Society and the Film Society.
 The intriguing triangular shape makes this one of the most iconic buildings in New York City!
Built in 1902 at the bustling intersection of Fifth Avenue and Broadway, this is one of the most photographed spots in the city today.
 Until next time, cheers!

 One World Trade Center
The monolithic One World Trade Center (also known as the Freedom Tower or One WTC) is the tallest building in the United States, tallest building in the western hemisphere and seventh-tallest building in the world.

research_results.content:
If you've got limited time or compatriots with limited attention spans, start with the Temple of Dendur, a 2,000-year-old soaring Egyptian temple (the only complete one in the Western Hemisphere)

Grand Central TerminalArrow
Grand Central Terminal is more than just one of the busiest train stations in the world—it's a window into old New York and into a time when train travel was the ultimate luxury for the wealthy and a necessity for the working man. North AmericaChevron

The 37 Best Things to Do in New York City
By Melissa Liebling-Goldberg and Alex Erdekian
One of the most mysterious things about New York City is that the closer you look—even at something as minor as a street corner—the more you see. Madison Flager
Megan Spurrell
Adele Chapin
Rachel Chang
Prospect ParkArrow
Prospect Park is in many ways the Central Park of Brooklyn; in fact, it was designed shortly after by the same team of architects, Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, and has many of the same features: sprawling meadows, walking trails, and picturesque bodies of water. It shows a curated roster of films that includes exclusive archival screenings, special premiers, and Q&As with notable filmmakers; a few of the films playing on the current lineup in November include The Wall, a 1990 documentary about the Berlin Wall with vérité-style footage; Bill Cunningham New York on 35mm film, introduced by director Richard Press and producer Philip Gefter; and the classic Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf, starring Elizabeth Taylor.

research_results.title: 14 of the best parks in New York City - Lonely Planet
research_results.content: Visit for a taste of why New York remains a truly global city. 6. Staten Island Greenbelt. Staten Island's natural beauty has always delighted conservationists, with 19th-century figures as prominent as Henry David Thoreau and Frederick Law Olmsted celebrating the ecological richness of its hills.

research_results.title: 22 Best Parks in New York City as per a Native New Yorker
research_results.content: Best Parks in NYC: The Best Parks In The Bronx Pelham Bay Park. As unexpected as this may sound, this park is the largest one in all of New York City! Central Park is a baby in comparison to Pelham Bay. If you're looking for hiking trails, you'll find them here. They have public golf courses and even designated horse-riding paths.

research_results.title: 15 Best Parks In NYC To Visit (2023) - Secret NYC
research_results.content: 10. Pelham Bay Park. Photo: Felix Lipov / Shutterstock. Pelham Bay Park is NYC's largest park, covering over 2,700 acres in the Bronx. You can find saltwater marshes, forested areas, and scenic trails all over the place, as well as picnic areas, sports fields, and hiking trails.

recommendations.title: Visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art
recommendations.description: One of the world's largest and finest art museums. Its collection includes over two million works of art spanning 5,000 years of world history.
recommendations.reasoning: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is a staple in New York and offers an extensive collection of art that can keep visitors engrossed for hours. Perfect for a budget-friendly visit with numerous exhibitions and often discounted tickets.

recommendations.title: Explore Central Park
recommendations.description: An urban park in Manhattan that offers sprawling meadows, walking trails, picturesque bodies of water, and historic landmarks. Great for picnics, jogging, and relaxing in the summer.
recommendations.reasoning: Central Park is a must-see in New York City, offering diverse recreational opportunities and scenic beauty, all for free. Ideal for a cost-effective, enjoyable day.

recommendations.title: Attend a Free Outdoor Concert
recommendations.description: Enjoy free music performances in various NYC parks during the summer, including SummerStage, Bryant Park 'Picnic Performances', and New York Philharmonic's 'Concert in the Parks'.
recommendations.reasoning: These concerts provide an excellent opportunity to experience New York’s vibrant cultural scene without spending much money, all while enjoying the beautiful summer weather.

recommendations.title: Watch a Movie in a Park
recommendations.description: Enjoy the warm summer evenings by watching free movies in city parks. Events like 'Movies Under the Stars' take place in various locations around the city.
recommendations.reasoning: It's a quintessential NYC summer activity that combines outdoor fun with free entertainment, making it a great budget-friendly option.

recommendations.title: Visit the Brooklyn Museum
recommendations.description: A renowned cultural institution with a wide-ranging collection of art, particularly strong in Egyptian antiquities, African art, and contemporary work. Admission is pay-what-you-wish.
recommendations.reasoning: The Brooklyn Museum is perfect for art lovers on a budget. Its 'pay-what-you-wish' policy makes it an accessible and enriching experience for any traveler.

recommendations.title: Walk Across the Brooklyn Bridge
recommendations.description: Take a walk across this iconic bridge that connects Manhattan and Brooklyn. It offers stunning views of the city skyline and the East River.
recommendations.reasoning: Walking the Brooklyn Bridge is one of the most iconic and cost-effective ways to experience New York City. It's free and provides excellent photo opportunities.

recommendations.title: Visit the Bronx Museum of the Arts
recommendations.description: An art museum that specializes in contemporary art and also highlights the work of under-represented artists. Admission is free.
recommendations.reasoning: This museum offers a unique cultural experience without the burden of an entry fee, making it perfect for budget-conscious travelers.

recommendations.title: Explore Prospect Park
recommendations.description: Designed by the same architects of Central Park, this Brooklyn park offers meadows, forests, lakes, and recreational facilities.
recommendations.reasoning: Prospect Park provides a serene escape from the hustle and bustle of the city, offering similar features to Central Park but often with fewer crowds. It's free to enter and enjoy.

recommendations.title: Visit Governors Island
recommendations.description: A unique island oasis just a short ferry ride from Lower Manhattan, offering historical forts, bike rentals, and outdoor art installations.
recommendations.reasoning: Governors Island is a cheap and quick escape from the city, with ferry rides costing just a few dollars and plenty of free activities once you arrive.

recommendations.title: Check Out the Staten Island Greenbelt
recommendations.description: A network of lush, green spaces on Staten Island, featuring hiking trails, nature centers, and scenic views.
recommendations.reasoning: This park offers a slice of nature and numerous free outdoor activities, perfect for budget-conscious travelers who enjoy hiking and exploring the outdoors.

recommendations.title: Visit Pelham Bay Park
recommendations.description: New York City's largest park, located in the Bronx, offering hiking trails, picnic areas, and scenic landscapes.
recommendations.reasoning: Pelham Bay Park provides a wide array of free outdoor activities and is less crowded than more famous parks, making it ideal for a budget-friendly day out.

recommendations.title: Explore the High Line
recommendations.description: A linear park built on a historic freight rail line elevated above the streets on Manhattan’s West Side, featuring lush gardens and stunning views of the Hudson River.
recommendations.reasoning: The High Line is a unique urban park experience and is free to visit, providing both scenic beauty and a touch of New York's history.

recommendations.title: Visit the Hispanic Society Museum & Library
recommendations.description: Home to Joaquín Sorolla's 'Vision of Spain' series and a broad collection of Hispanic art and cultural artifacts. Admission is free.
recommendations.reasoning: This museum offers a deep dive into Hispanic culture and art at no cost, making it a meaningful and wallet-friendly addition to your itinerary.

recommendations.title: Explore Times Square
recommendations.description: The bustling heart of Midtown Manhattan, famous for its bright lights, Broadway theaters, and electronic billboards.
recommendations.reasoning: A visit to Times Square is essential for any NYC trip and is free to experience. It’s the perfect place for people-watching, photography, and soaking in the vibrant city atmosphere.
